title: Wanhao Duplicator i3/MP Maker Select i3 Bowden Cold End Extruder Mount

description.text:
I wanted a simple bowden cold end extruder mount that would fit right under my top mounted filament reel or be flexible enough to slide to another position to support an enclosure mounted filament reel as well. This is what I came up with and it works perfectly for me, so I figured I'd share it in case someone else needs a simple mount.

Once the stepper bracket is bolted to this part, you just slide it on. It has a snug pressure fit clip on the back that keeps it firmly in place.

Instructions:

  1. Print the attached STL file. (Brim suggested to help it stick to plate).
  2. On the surface with 6 holes, use four of those holes to bolt your extruder stepper motor bracket into place. I suggest using M3 bolts with nyloc nuts.
  3. Simply slide the bracket assembly bolted to this part onto the top of the i3 frame as pictured and pull it toward you about 5 to 8 millimeters to allow the pressure fit clip to engage.

Printer:

Maker Select i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a 5mm brim for the first two layers to help keep the part from detaching from the print bed.

title: "Party Snap" Grenade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
For some explosive fun that you can 3D print at home, I've designed a grenade that's filled with "Party Snaps".

The grenade is composed of three pieces: the plunger, the head, and the body. All three pieces are supplied as individual STLs, so you only need to print what you need when it comes to replacement parts. While you can print and use the grenade at 50%, I recommend you stick with 75% or larger based on my testing.

For instructions and testing results, please view the video at: https://youtu.be/_BEe5IxEdss

comments.text:
This looks like it could be fun. Looking at your design, might I suggest a couple of mods. 1, make the striker/plunger diameter only slightly less than the firing platform that way no breakages and a greater striking area, this could be profiled the same as the body. 2, only use 1 layer of snaps to minimise any cushioning effect which will result in misfires 3, make it double ended for twice the fun.
I dont understand 3D design so cannot do it myself. I do have boxes of fun snaps and lots of chums to "blow up" :)

comments.text: 1) The plunger will likely have a larger diameter plunger on the next version.  However, as long as the model is printed at 75% or larger, the plunger didn't break during any of the testing (which was much longer than the video shows).

description.text:
Smaller revised version of my normal sized TPU soft mounts. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2018045

This is a quick and effective way to dampen those motor vibrations resonating through your carbon frame and confusing your Flight Controller.

Print solid with soft TPU and squish them between your motors and your frame.

TRICKS FOR PRINTING TPU:

I've managed to print NinjaFlex with some pretty crappy extruders

Direct Drive probably easier. But I have seen a 3mm bowden work.

Print SUPER SLOW
Print HOT like 230º
130% extrusion multiplier. TPU likes to compress and under extrude.

good luck.

title: Adjustable Modular 3D printed Spreader Bar for B D S M fun Mk2

description.text:
Mk2 version - a bit less weight, printed with S3D /75% fill/standard S3D support

Disguising a long Spreader Bar when flying or going to a Hotel can be a challenge - my Clip-Together All-Plastic Spreader Bar will fix the problem.
How many sections do I need

The MALE End is 40mm long, female and Joiner sections are 90mm long.

So both end sections and 4 joiners gives 580mm total length, or 6 joiners = 760mm.

I used ABS with S3D standard support & 80% infill - less infill % may be OK, but who wants a subbie getting loose (without her safeword, of course)

A small amount of filing so the parts easily twist together and lock, and you're good to go, - but not your sub - who isn't going anywhere.

title: OOTS solar light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
(Out of the shadows solar light)

This thing is a solar garden light that is 3D printable.
Printed in ABS filament and glued together with acetone

The design was born from the desire to have a bright and reliable solar light,one that would be very bright,lighting up an area rather that just be for decoration.
I was tired of seeing only tiny,not fit for purpose solar led lights.
So i have designed my own 3D printed version.

The sides of the unit are bevelled on all edges so that once glue is applied the main body becomes very rigid and strong.
The windows are 1.0 mm thick printed clear ABS filament or cab be laser cut out of acrylic sheet.
More updates and build photos to follow shortly,enjoy :-)

ABS filament black + clear.

Acetone or super glue
Needle applicator bottle

10.0 mm led lamp x 1
18650 battery x 2
Single 18650 battery holder x 2
Solar charge controller x 1 ,eBay item number:131587598844

1 x M10 bolt @ 30mm
x 1 piece of aluminium baking foil or drinks can
Hot melt glue gun
A few pieces of electrical wire
Soldering iron + solder

title: Nintendo Switch Joystick Extender Mod 1.4 REMIX for 3 legs

description.text:
I made one of the original Nintendo Switch Joystick Extender Mod 1.4 (WIP) and two of a slight variant I created in advance of even doing the original due to the feedback in the comments of the original. My slight variation was to just cut off one of the legs, and that part works great. It slides on and off the thumb stick quite easily and is firm when in use.

I also embeded the inlaid word "Switch" on the bottom. I'm not really sure why I did that - it's pointless.

I only messed with the concave option, but I found that applying a "dollup" of hot glut to the center of the concave area allowed a texture that was much more pleasant to use.

comments.text: I'd remove the word Switch or offer an STL without it - you're right, it's pointless and, honestly, introduces risk of print failure for such a small print.

comments.text: You think that's bad, I have the beta ABS/PLA version. I could never get ABS to print right. Now that I've got the PLA going for me, I discovered that for some reason it goes completely off on the y axis for large builds (or multiple small items thus making it a larger build). I tried to build the other spool holder for space reasons but everything went bad. Luckily, this one fits because I can rotate it to build horizontally.
comments.author: zinoy

comments.text: I realize this is a rather old post but I've had that exact problem on several prints of other parts, using both PLA and ABS. The root cause usually seems to be in either the z-axis being off, or the tension on the filament is too strong/weak. Even if you have the auto bed leveling version of the Robo3d the z-axis is the most common issue. Make sure the coupler nut is seated properly and fitting into the guide far enough that the limit switches don't slip off and spin on the threaded rod. That's what fixed my problem.
comments.author: zinoy

comments.text:
Tough to say the exact problem so I'll list a few,
-If the E3d is like the Robo3D hex it takes a bit more heat than before, I do PLA at 210 now. bed at 55 for the first layer than off after that.
-Print 2 at the same time so the layers harden up before getting printed on again.
-I use the purple aqua net and love it, blue tape actually works really well if you have some.
-last resort, make sure the print fan is on and slow down the print until the letters get covered.

Have you ever been discouraged by how unprofessional LEDs look sticking out of a breadboard? Have you felt frustrated by the exposed leads and  helpless to do anything about it? description.text:
This is a new version for the X-axis belt tensioner.
I redesigned it to make easy adjustments to the X-axis and Z-axis.
Release pressure on Z-axis smooth rods and bearings.
The lead screws stay straight, don't wobble anymore.

Instruction:
Glue the rod caps to the left of the X-axis where the motor is located. (picture 3)
Open the box to the right of the X-axis and remove the acrilyk which is in the center of the box. (picture 4)
Instale the new version.
Adjust the distance of the X-axis rods from the Z-axis rods by adjusting the screws.
After that, tight the belt of the X-axis after.

Have a good print!!

description.text:
UPDATED 7/23/2017
Added my logo version for anyone that like my logo and/or wants to advertise.. lol. Just seemed a waste not to publish the file.
Depending on accuracy of print some hot glue may be require to how SD card reader in holder.

UPDATED 4/1/2017
After having some fitment issues with the latest batch of extender cables and having to do way too much filling to make them fit I have increased the size of the housing portion (no change to the front bezel) by 1mm in width and height. now they fit with zero sanding required.. New file ends in V4..

This is designed to hold an SD card extender cable. I used two 25inch cables (one MicroSD to SD and one SD to SD) to extend the SD card on the motherboard to a location on the front of the printer.

I removed the cover from the SD extender cable and slid the cable in thru the holder feeding the cable end thru the slot, then just pushed the circuit board in place till it is seated. Then just attach the two cables together and hide it all under the top covers.

Cables were run to follow the same root as the front display cable.

Removal of all outer covers is required to locate in same location and a small notch must be cut in the metal frame as well. I used a Dremel with a carbide cutting wheel to cut the cover and metal frame.

If anyone knows where to source a MicroSD to SD extender cable that is 48inches long please let me know. It would make the install much simpler as the only sources I can find for 25inch cables are in China.

Updated on 3/20/2017 - Added a rotatable front for those that don't like my angle and two stocks for those not wanting to use a real AR15 stock.

I couldn't find a Vive stock that I liked so I mixed the best two I could find. I utilized the front controller from this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1828084 design to put the mote in the correct orientation for onward. I used the weaver rails, stock mount and the remote mount from this stock http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1745148 for the back remote. I upgraded to four magnets from 2 because with two my mote keep falling out. I added an adjustable ar15 stock to be able to custom fit it quickly for the various eye reliefs on the different guns in onward. I have been using it for a couple weeks without issue and it is a great improvement over my other stocks. If you alternate the orientation of the magnets it makes reattaching the back remote with the headset on insanely simple and quick after healing or throwing a grenade. I printed this on an Anet A8 and used all 220mm of the bed.

If you are using this and see CareBears-LuvALot in game let me know.

title: Da Vinci 1.0 E3D V6 drop in remix

description.text:
UPDATE: 03/09/2017
So I saw last night that the original creator of the E3D mount revised his design to better direct the air away from the print bed. To stay current I have updated both the Base and backing plate to incorporate his updated design. I have also updated the backing plate and layer cooling fan shroud to allow the shroud to be secured to the backing plate for easier removal when the layer cooling fan isn't needed. The new files all end in V2.

Ok so this is my remix off all the upgrades I liked from my E3D v6 conversion. I've integrated the cable chain mounts and a guide for the PTFE tubing. I've also added in the fan duct and fan cover for repurposing the stock fan for layer cooling.

Cable chain mount now uses heat sets instead of nut inserts. I used 21 links and the end mount of the 10x15 cable chain.

I've added a second version of this fan duct that should eliminate the need to feed the belt thru it and provide additional print bed clearance(first version hits the mount screws in the four corners of my print bed). I have not yet tested this in my printer.

Please see the original builds for further installation notes

description.text:
Using another design for the camera mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023540
Mounts in a little better location (IMHO) and has an opening in the front to avoid pressing the bind button on the Furibee board. Also, if you're very handy with a soldering iron you can A: stop the swamping issue that this board has and B: Enable SBUS.

==============================

I printed the design by DavidJohnson and really like, but it had some design issues for my build. The frame is super light and this flies more like a micro quad than most Tiny Whoops as (i believe) the ducts have been removed, which improves airflow. It's a bit more of a slippery flier ... it glides a bit more than a standard whoop. It's fun!

I printed this in Taulman 910 and Taulman PCTPE (scaled on the Z axis a bit). Both work. The 910 is great ... it has survived an unbelievable number of crashes. The PCTPE is a borderline too flexible but it definitely works - it's probably impossible to break though. I used RIT dye to dye the parts.

WHY THE REMIX? The original design didn't work very well in the standard configuration where you mash the board between the camera mount and the frame. The support braces for the frame interfere with the JST headers for the motors ... and you can't really assemble it. I didn't notice this on the first frame I assembled because I had already torn the headers off .......... This design just completes the motor guard circle and re-orients the support braces for rigidity and allows the JST headers to drop right in.

Also wanted to add some motor protection (i printed them in PCTPE).

As far as printing nylon. Besides the drying issue ... printing nylon has been easier than printing PLA.

I think the frame is around 3g.

This is a hack job remix of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1808557

Notes:

Prusa MKII

This insert helps with aligning the hex wrenches with the bottom hole of the holder. Though it was designed for this specific wrench set: http://www.harborfreight.com/10-pc-metric-t-handle-hex-key-set-69370.html it should work with similar sets.

No

20%

Hex Wrench alignment assistant

So I bought the metric hex wrench set from Harbor Freight (http://www.harborfreight.com/10-pc-metric-t-handle-hex-key-set-69370.html) for a good deal. The holder is S-shaped sheet metal with holes on the top and mid-section for holding the wrenches and I was constantly struggling to line up the wrench with the top and bottom holes. Since I kept it under my desk, it got to the point that I avoided taking the wrenches out because of the pain of putting them back in. I made this part so that I can just drop the wrench in the top hole and it lines up the wrench with the bottom hole automatically. Works great. And just putting the wrenches thru the part the first time, keeps the part from coming out and gluing it in is not required.

A simple round stand base for Lego minifigures in the Lego Dimensions style.

Update: June 2017 Adjusted the nub size slightly and added some more style. It doesn't blend with the dimensions stuff quite as well now but I like it more. Also, I've found printing with a flexible filament works really well. Right now I'm using "Tough 3d Ink". It isn't nearly as flimsy as it looks in the ads and the elastic quality works really well for the compression fit on Legos. One other note, I based the center of the new part on a file I had on my disk, so the update is a remix of something. My apologies to the origial creator of part "round.stl"; I don't know who you are.

Original: I'm going to mark this one done. These work well enough to blend right in with the Dimensions sets. I'm still not thrilled with the fit though. It works fine with a little sanding and it's made to Lego specs but right off the printer it's a tight fit. I've had varied luck with the output though, so I'm going to assume it's my printing and not the model. If anyone has any thoughts, let me know. I'll likely come back with a version 2 given Dimension's popularity around the house.

title: Melzi board - mounting plate for Prusa - snap fit

there are some objects for melzi and prusa, but they where too big to print it on 210x210 bed and they are not mounted like i whanted to have it. on the picture (the protoype) there are 8 nibbles to snap it, but i removed 4 of them, cause its now more easy to snap it togerther.

title: X Axis Belt Tensioner for P802E

description.text:
remix of a remix, to work with the default hardware from a TronXY P802E(well, mostly, had to use some 8-32 x 2" bolt and nut since it's 20mm length is already too long for any of the supplied hardware).
might be a tight fit on the default bearing supplied with my P802E(it's way too large!), but could work(may need some oil. hehe).

v4: i missed expanding one of the holes to fit the 8-32 bolt. lol

v6: found some tiny ball bearings from an old fan, i've adapted them to work for this. the bolt holding the bearing is a tiny 2.5mm one that was in the spare bolts bag that came from the P802E, i think they are used on the X axis end-stop.

edit: using the default hardware from the P802E, did not work, the belt needed much more height to work properly. but if you have a smaller bearing, you can use that to get this item working properly.

description.text:
*Current file about .2 mm out of being concentric to the stepper motor shaft. At the moment I am shimming it and running tests. After I confirm this solves wobble artifacts, I'll update the file with the appropriate size.

Bearing mounts to make 8mm lead screw run in the center and parallel to 2040 on the Reach3D printer in order to reduce side to side wobble. Mount is designed for 608ZZG bearings and you'll need 2 M5x10 bolts and 2 flat t nuts per mount. Printing only one will work, however, two will make sure it is parallel. You'll have to use flat t nuts to secure it to the 2040 because there are ridges that run in the v grooves of the 2040 in order to center the mount. If you do put the mount on the bottom one, you'll have to move the Y endstop to the side of the 2040. A new endstop mount can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2161342

Version "000004" was modeled as a single part. I'm a bit new to 3D printing, but this version has proven difficult for me to print well, even with supports. My prints turned out a bit bumpy. If you have suggestions on how best to print this as a single piece, please let me know.

Version "000008" comes in 3 separate parts that must be assembled. The fit is a little tight and I had to carefully hammer these together, but they printed a lot easier. You can also assemble this to make different sizes, depending on how many pieces you print. For the standard size, you will need to print 1 of the P1 parts, 1 of the P3 parts, and 5 of the P2 parts.

If you make this, please post a photo of your print. I'd be interested in seeing how well it comes out for you.

description.text:
Y.A.P.S - Yet Another Phone Stand

This sturdy phone stand has 6 viewing angles and should work for most smart phones, even with large cases. The stand is raised to allow for charging while in an upright position.
You can print the optional add-ons/mods for each side, like the wallet-sized picture frame included. I'll add more add-ons as time permits.
I print this at .3 resolution PLA with 1.2 mm walls, 0% infill with support and just a skirt for base adhesion. Make sure the bracket is facing the right direction when inserting into the sides.

[edited 3/10/2017]: I made a minor change to the picture frame add-on. The connector shaft and the side of the frame wasn't aligned properly, and I shortened the length of the picture frame and widened the frame edge 1mm so standard photos (2.5 in x3.5 in) should fit better.

No

Yes

.3 mm

0%

Notes:

At this resolution and speed 50, it takes about 2.5 hours on my printer for the stand and about 25 mins for the picture frame.

The picture frame add-on is optional and requires good contact cement to glue the connecting shaft and the 4 corner pieces that hold the picture in place.

Assembling the stand

After cleaning up any support material, connect the bottom and top hinges to the inner facing holes on the sides and work them around a bit making sure they rotate fine and that the hinges are oriented properly. Remove one of the sides and connect the small support bracket to the side making sure that the side with the bumps is facing the front of the stand and it should click into place. Connect the other side to the support bracket while aligning the top and bottom hinges to the holes in the side.

Alternatively, you can connect the support bracket to the sides first, then place the hinges in the side holes while slightly twisting the sides. Just be careful not to twist too much causing the bracket to break.

Assembling the optional wallet-sized picture frame add-on

Good contact cement or other adhesive/glue is required for the picture frame add-on. The connector shaft is glued to the side of the picture frame that has the rectangular tab. The 4 corner pieces are glued to the 4 corners on the back using the raised pegs on the back side of the frame as guides and applying the glue to the raised corner only so that the corners of a photo can slide in.

Contact cement the support shaft to the tab on the front of the picture frame Contact cement the 4 pieces to the back side of the picture frame making sure that the corners of a photo will be able to slide in

This is based on a foam board phone stand I created a couple years ago.
I drew the concept on my iPad and modeled it in SketchUp where it has gone through several iterations and tweaks.

remixed_from.title: Air Raid Siren - hand crank version 2

title: Air Raid Siren - modified stronger version

description.text:
I printed the air raid siren version 2 and ran into some problems when I built it, so I made some modifications to make the siren more durable.

Slicing with a slicer that can print multiple models at once with different infill settings is pretty much required. I used simplify3d.

To build this you need these metric [mm] bearings:
(amount x outer diameter / inner diameter / height - model#)

1 x 47/25/12 - SKF 6005-2Z
4 x 16/5/5 - SKF 625-2Z

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

print everything at 0.2mm and 20% infill with the exceptions noted below:

  1. print SirHa_Gehause1 or the split version SirHa_Gehause1handle / SirHa_Gehause1klein
  2. SirHa_Gehause2 has built in supports, print without support
  3. print SirHa_Gehause3 or the split version for dual extrusion
  4. SirHa_GetrRad1 has been broken into 3 parts: hub, spokes, and teeth. print the hub and teeth solid 100% infill, and the spokes 20%
  5. SirHa_GetrRad2A and SirHa_GetrRad3 have been combined into SirHa_GetrRad23, then split into hub, spokes, and teeth. print the hub and teeth solid 100% infill, and the spokes 20%
  6. SirHa_GetrRad2B goes in the bottom of SirHa_GetrRad23. print this solid.
  7. SirHa_GetrRad4A and SirHa_GetrRad4B both should be printed solid.
  8. print SirHa_Kurbel1_spaced or the split version SirHa_Kurbel1 / SirHa_Kurbel1_spacer. the spacer keeps the handle tight against the bearing and keeps the first gear and handle in alignment much better.
  9. SirHa_Kurbel2 - print the thread layers and a little into the handle solid
  10. print SirHa_Rotor1_blades and SirHa_Rotor1_spindle together, with blades at 20% infill and spindle solid
  11. print SirHa_Rotor3 at 0.1mm layer height.
  12. print 3x SirHa_Schraube1 and 6x SirHa_Schraube2, I printed mine solid and a little undersized (95% scale)
  13. the spacer for Kurbel1 makes a huge difference for SirHa_Schraube3. I printed it on its side with supports, and solid. This makes the screw a lot stronger in the rotational axis, which is required when using the spacer.

comments.text: I was just reading your Thing's description and I have a suggestion:  Point out that "625-2Z" bearings are the same as "625ZZ" bearings.  On Amazon (in the US) the 625ZZ version is much cheaper.  If someone just searches for "625-2Z" they won't see the cheaper version (which is identical).
comments.author: riskable

comments.text: I believe your thing is missing some files.  For example, the SirHa_Rotor1_spindle and SirHa_Rotor1_blades that your description speaks of do not exist.
comments.author: riskable

comments.text: Thanks! I've uploaded them and a few more (I think there might be some dupes now too). Let me know if you run into any more missing parts.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/d1TekQFb7GB

The crossbow is designed for rubber bands.

Requires support on the back on the end and middle of the "stock". Also support on the levitated arms is recommended.

The pins at the firing mechanism might need a few millimeters higher. Larger rubber bands can slip off from the pins.

A tip for ammunition is to take a plastic straw and cut it ranging from 6-8 centimeters, then fill one end with wet paper for ballast.

Additional thoughts: the nock could be wider if possible as "straw arrows" can tend to slip off. The lever mechanism can become stuck to the mount. I solved this with a needle and picked away plastic that was in the way.

Have fun!

title: Water Meter Wrench, for a 5 sided fastener

description.text:
If you have a residential/commercial water meter cover that has a 5 sided bolt on the lid that is 0.82" (20.8 mm) from a flat to a tip, this wrench allows you to open the lid to read the meter or shut off the main water valve.
I made it after helping my son replace the primary water valve inside his home. This would have made opening the lid a lot easier.

Printed this flat, cleaned up as needed, try it on the bolt head, and use a rotary grinder as necessary until it fits the fastener.
For additional strength (if you are concerned about loosening a tight lid) a metal band could be placed around the circular portion of the wrench.

comments.text: I tried this, but the walls were simply too thin to get my meter open - too many years of dirt getting into the threads of that bolt, I believe.  I'd recommend thickening the walls or going with an insert for a metal socket so the socket walls provide reinforcement.

title: Needle File Handle w/ Thumb Set Screw

description.text: This is a re-work of "Parametric Magnetic Driver Bit Handle" to be used with Needle File Sets. I Narrowed the handle a bit, adapted the shaft hole, and added a slot for a 6-32 square nut to help hold the needle files in place with a thumb screw. Works really well + a good amount of grip for large hands. (no, its not parametric anymore, just expand the hole a tiny bit with a hot drill bit, if the files wont go in.)

I did this mod for a set of "HF" needle files. these files are not exactly a good example of precision engineering, there shafts differ in diameter greatly even along the length of the same file! but what i did is size it for the smallest, then i worked the smallest into the shaft and wiggled it around a bit, then moved up to the next largest,. and so on,. until the largest could just barely fit, then the thumb screw helps lock in the smaller ones. its intentionally a very tight fit.  
Square Nut slot is Sized for 6-32

comments.text:
Very nice handles! I made a change to accommodate a M3x5 socket head cap screw with hex drive and an according M3 nut.

title: Basic snap clasp for "Xiaomi Mi Band 2 replacement wrist band"

description.text:
A basic snap clasp for the "Xiaomi Mi Band 2 replacement wrist band / chain" by smartformat (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2133865)

The original band is to be closed by magnets, but the Mi Band 2 has to be holded snug against the user wrist to be able to measure the heart rate. In my case, the magnetic locking was not usable, so I designed this very basic yet functional snap clasp for it.

The assembly instructions are included in the OpenSCAD comments. You just need two small pieces (about 2 x 15mm) of 1.75mm filament in addition to printing one "open" clip and one "closed" clip.

author: DonJuanito

title: TKO90 for 20x20
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is my "TKO" 90mm brushless TinyKwad. I have about 50 hours into designing and testing this frame. It's super light and really fun. BUT... it does break, I'm refining and testing the design everyday. This is actually revision 29. I found that the tunnels I had in the booms didn't make it easy to swap to a new frame if a boom broke so I've made slots for the motor wires to slide into. This way you don't have to cut wires or re-solder anything to switch out a broken frame.

Updates: 3/11/2017 Removed boom tunnels so frame swap can be solderless.
3/13/2017 Added 1mm step to perimeter for overall strength.

I'm currently running a Pico Blx FC, Cicada 10A 4 in1 ESC, Spektrum Sat, AIO FPV Cam, 1102 7800kv motors and 2030 2in props on 2S 300mah.

Hope you enjoy and please share your builds with me.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

20

title: 3D Printer Enclosure - Ikea Lack Legs Remix with Perspex Guides

description.text:
zuspiel's design is amazing, definitely check out his Source files.

I wanted to add in some Acrylic/Perspex guides for my 3mm thick clear Acrylic sheet so I remixed his design. My Acrylic was sold as 3mm, I measured it and it was thinker so the cutouts are approx 3.5mm which is fine for some extra as it makes it easier to slide the top on and off.

My idea is to keep the design so that the top enclosure can be taken off including the perspex, there is a bolt hole on the top section to keep it all in place and the bottom guides just help it sit together.

All credit to Zuspiel, thanks heaps!

title: Tent Guy Rope Hook and Shackle

description.text:
Hook and shackle set for tent guy ropes.

On a recent camping trip, it began raining as I was setting up the tent. Whilst I was tying off the guy ropes (in the rain), I thought of this hook and shackle arrangement to make tying off faster. I leave the shackles tied off to the tent permanently and simply clip the hook to the shackle.

I haven't had an opportunity to test the hooks and shackle in the outdoors yet. However, I am confident that it will be suitable. UPDATE: They work well :) . I'm also testing out my own flavour of a guy rope cinch.

Components are printed in PETG which has excellent strength properties.

Scanned with the sadly now nonexistent 123D Catch app. The raw file is included. Then I brought this into Blender for cleanup. After cleanup, there were some non manifold parts that had to be deleted and I reduced the polygons so it would slice faster. After this, I exported as x3d because Cura 2.3 can't open a direct stl export from Blender for some reason but it can open an x3d export. Saved as stl from Cura. If you open pawn.blend, the cleaned/sculpted scan is on the right. The middle are the two pieces that are being reduced after the remesh operation (a boolean operation still has to be done with the base) and the right is the reduced and merged result. The right model is available by itself as pawn-remeshed.blend.

Print the base upside down and the holder sideways.

Mount the upper part to the base either with 2 M4 screws (10mm) or melt in M3 nuts in the upper part (these special melt-in nuts, I love them...).

Print settings or material are not critical here.
I printed with white PLA, 0.1mm layers, 2 perimeters, 25% infill, 45mm/s.

description.text:
This design is a remix of a design published on Appropedia. We started out with their original design, with the intent of supplying 3D printed otoscopes to health posts in Nepal as part of the earthquake response. After gaining user feedback from a range of medical practitioners in the UK and Nepal, we have arrived at this design.

For more information on assembly and the electronics, please visit the Wevolver page.

Speculas are intended as disposable items. Please discard after use.

Thanks to Humanitarian Maker Ram Chandra for this design.

Printer:

UP Printers

Resolution:

less than or equal to 0.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

-For the specula, it is better to use a dark coloured filament (preferably black).
-There are two specula with narrow opening and wider opening. Meant to be for children and Adult.
-There are two Lens_assy for different lens thickness. Use accordingly.

If printing only speculas, be careful of print errors near the tip of the specula. If printing a single specula, the narrow circular geometry of the tip means that the print head moves very fast without pausing, and this can mean that the layers do not cool properly before the next layer is printed. This can lead to a 'melted' effect. To prevent this happening, it is recommended to print a minimum of 3 speculas simultaneously, or to print 2 speculas with one of them in an inverted orientation.

Support: It should work fine with support angle less than 10 degree with the suggested orientation of Print.

Orientation: as in STL files

A fume extractor for electronics.

It uses a 70 mm fan with up to 95 mm thickness.

Also, it uses an active carbon for filtering.

Micro brushless quadcopter frame, inspired by the Martian / Alien style.

Parts list:

  1. This frame
  2. Racerstar BR1103 motors
  3. Eachine minicube stack (PDB,ESC,FC and Rx) - spacers as follows: 2.5mm from frame, 4mm between ESC and FC, 4mm between FC and Rx, 4mm on top of Rx then top plate.
  4. Eachine AIO FPV VTx/Cam (from Aurora - mount at 25 degrees)
  5. JST female plug (space to mount this at the back of the quad)
  6. M2 x 25mm hex screws - for mounting the minicube stack and fixing top and bottom plates together
  7. M2 nyloc bolts
  8. 10mm wide velcro strap for holding the battery
  9. Double sided tape/superglue for VTx and JST connector
  10. 2s LiPo with JST male plug (XF Power 600mah 30c has nice long JST lead for this)
  11. Props - frame can probably take up to about 60mm diameter
  12. Paint - plastic one coat paint

28 March 17 - Found some nylon screws that were long enough, so have updated parts list. Also mounting holes (top and bottom plates) reduced to fit

27 March - Increased lens hole size for easier build (it was pretty tight previously) and extended cam 25 degree mount

14 March 17 - Added 'ramp' access to the arm from the motor mounts as the Racerstar motor wires are inflexible

13 March 17 - Amended top plate camera antenna hole to account for 25 degree slope. Also updated top plate to leave some clearance for the cam angle

12 March 17 - First print successful however the built-in standoffs are VERY tight to push the screws through. Have updated. Also updated the spacers to provide more internal wiggle room

9 March 17 - the cam mount area needed to be off-centre to align the lens centrally but I've realised I also moved the lens hole in the front... headslap. Now updated

8 March 17 - updated top plate to include notch for buzzer

Note: If you hadn't guessed, the small hole in the top plate is for the Rx antenna and the small slot is for a zip tie in order to secure the antenna in the tried and tested heatshrink method

Here are links to most of the parts in the parts list. If it isn't included below, I already had one. These are affiliate links so I would get a small kick-back if you order direct from here. Up to you if you do it or not

  1. Frame: You can tip me if you wish!
  2. Motors: http://bit.ly/2mj8W4s
  3. Eachine minicube (PDB, ESCs, FC and Rx): http://bit.ly/2mYv6vV
  4. Cam/VTx: http://bit.ly/2nICrPW
  5. JST female plug: http://bit.ly/2mYsFJD
  6. M2 x 25mm nylon hex screws - eBay
  7. M2 nyloc bolts - eBay
  8. 2s LiPo: http://bit.ly/2lYfKCK
  9. Props: http://bit.ly/2oc7lRa / http://bit.ly/2lYvOUQ

description.text:
[EDIT] Take V3 versions of models on the download section instead of V2, some correction have been applied.

Welcome on the Super Game Pi 64 !

Inspired by the excellent adafruit, thanks to Carasibana and his projet Super Game PiSP for the Start/Select buttons.
Hi guys, I spent hours on this game console. On the design first, to make it as small as possible (while keeping performance) and on the mapping buttons for some emulators that didn't work great on the original project found on adafruit. I named it "Super Game Pi 64" because I started with the adafruit super game Pi project and I made a lot of changes to upgrade the game console and make the N64 works with GPIO buttons :)

The specs :

  • Size : 105.5x155x30mm
  • Time playing : up to 5-6 hours tested with full charged battery.
  • Time charging battery from empty : loonng time. Around 10-11h.
  • How many usable buttons : 14 + joystick. There is 2 on the back, 5 on the cross with the clic, 1 on the joystick (clic also) 6 on the front.
  • USB gamepad : Allowed yes ! Up to 4 (I tried with 2). So great to play in multiplayer mode on TV screen HDMI with multiple gamepad !
  • Multiplayer : So yes works great with USB gamepad. Should work on all emulators, I tried Snes, megadrive and N64.
  • Screen : small and cheap screen. But really enough for retrogaming. I had a better screen on the previous version, but it used to work on the HDMI plug (see the adafruit project)... And I really prefered design a game console with a smaller screen that is really enough good to works on standalone mode, and having the HDMI plug available to play on TV. The screen is plugged in composite mode.
  • Screen settings : yes : brightness, contrast, saturation, tint, language. The 3 small buttons on the side do it.
  • External HDMI : hell yeaahh ! Just switch off, plug the HDMI, switch on and enjoy !
  • Sound : no internal sound. Jack plug available. There still room up to the battery to fit some but I've tried on the previous version and I had a lot of noise even if I tuned off the sound in Retropie. So I decided to cut off internal sound.
  • Saving/load states : yes for all. I map a specific button to it. For all emulator but N64 and NDS : Select+Save/load state button. For N64 and NDS : just press Save/load state button.

Emulators :

I tested some of them (actually the consoles I had when I was a child), all are working really great (nes, gameboy advance, supernes, megadrive, and more...). And specially :
  • N64 : wooorrkkinnngg so great ! That was the biggest problem : games where launching but didn't work on standalone game console (just with USB gamepad). So I spent a lot of time on modifying files and I also add and map the little cross button on the side so you can use C button of the N64 gamepad with it. Works great.
  • NDS : works great ! Mapping button was made indide the emulator settings with the game console plugged in HDMI.
  • Playstation : Works great, that is crasy ! Use the cross button on the side to map L2 / R2.
  • Dreamcast : working but not with GPIO buttons. See "Regrets" section.

Why not smaller version :

I didn't make this game console for people to watch it, but to play it. So 3 reasons to the size, because I have 3 things that take a lot of place inside the game console.
  1. Raspberry pi 3B : you can make a retropie game console with a raspberry pi Zero (cheaper, smaller). BUT you won't have enough power to run n64, playstation, psp and dreamcast. AND it doesn't have double video connection : composite and HDMI. So I choose RPI3B
  2. Battery : you can use a smaller battery like the 2500maH. But I really wanted to have a loonngg time on the go with it. 5-6 hours is great I think.
  3. Joystick : this part is pretty big inside and work with a cupcade. So I could use the same joystick I used for the ilttle cross button on the side and save a lot of place inside. BUT the little one is not really playable as a real D-Pad for long terme. And the joystick Adafruit use on their original project is really pleasant to play. So I manage to keep it.

Why use SNES button but not tacticle :

On the previous version I used tacticle switches for the colored buttons as you can see in the Super game PiSP, and I actually tried smallers one. This is really not playable for long term : too much sound with the "clic", each time you use it. Imagine play a submarine level of Mario64 where you need to swim. People around you will be angry very fast with that noise, belive me that is
unbearable !

By the way, there is not enough room for tacticle switches :)

See instructions for some explainations .
Thanks for reading !

https://youtu.be/EUXoH-DOapo
https://youtu.be/Z_TxG3q0bKQ
https://youtu.be/HQCEqEDNaUU

RepRap

RepRap Kossel

No

No

0.2

50

Notes:

I have a small printer so I designed it to fit into it.
The biggest part is : 106x98mm
The highest part is : 26.5mm

I hope you can print on your printer !

I'll be honnest, I don't respond really often to comments. So I'll try to give you as much details as I can in this section and with photos. I'm sure you can handle it :) By the way I spend hours on modifying files... And I'll give you theses in the download section. You're welcome :)

Installing software

I use the 4.1 version of retropie (for RP3)
report to the excellent tutorial of adafruit : https://learn.adafruit.com/super-game-pi

-BUT don't copy lines in the "config.txt" file. Just don't touch to that file.

Wiring

report aslo to the same tutorial

-Wire also the C buttons and the Load/Save state button. See the GPIO photo. Use the joystick clic button for load (directly on the joystick circuit, not on the cupcade). Use the clic of the cross button for save.

On my made, I did solder wires directly on the Raspberry Pi 3B, but you can use the Adafruit way for pin, there is enough room for this. You'll need to buy this.

Wiring screen

See on the photos I upload where to solder the yelow wire on the back of the Raspberry Pi 3B. Take of the white wire of t he screen. Black and red wire directly on the - and + of the powerboost. Keep buttons to set screen contrast, brightness, etc... and hot glue them in the case.

Hot glue is your friend

  • hot glue the screen
  • hot glue to lock screen buttons
  • hot glue the battery
  • hot glue Start/select PCB
  • hot glue the cross button and the printed cross on it
  • hot glue to lock snes button
  • hot glue to lock L/R buttons

Snes buttons

Guess what... report to the same tutorial

Files to change :

Here is the coolest part : you need to replace / copy files to make every thing working fine. See in the download section for files.

Use a FTP client as Filezilla to copy them.

  • Adress : IP of your Raspberry Pi connected by ethernet (or wifi)
  • Login : pi
  • pass : raspberry
  • port : 22
boot folder

replace "retrogame.cfg"

opt/retropie/configs/all folder

replace "retroarch.cfg"

opt/retropie/configs/n64

copy "InputAutoCfg.ini"
replace "mupen64plus.cfg"

opt/retropie/configs/nds/drastic/config

On fresh install of retropie, theses folder don't exist. You need to install "Drastic" manually for Nintendo DS emulator : in "Retropie setup" menu. See in "experimental package" and look for "Drastic".
replace "drastic.cfg"

etc/emulationstation/themes/carbon
this will adapt the size of the text in menus of retropie. Otherwise you'll not be able to read the game names.

Use a SSH command as Putty to edit the file : "carbon.xml
Change the "fontsize" line 76 with 0.046
(check carbon.xml if you wanna be sure)
Save and reboot with the reboot command line.

Parts on mine :

  • 23 small screw m3
  • 2 screw m3x5
  • Raspberry pi 3B
  • this screen
  • this gamepad (take the same if you don't want to rebuild the 3D model)
  • Power boost 1000C
  • Start / Select button + Grey caps adapted on Snes L/R button
  • Battery 6600mAh Lithium Ion
  • Cupcade
  • joystick
  • PCB for start/select button to cut
  • switch on/off
  • joystick for the cross button See on download section the manual

Okay I think it's all. Enjoy !

I couldn't fine the way to map GPIO buttons for the dreamcast. I tried a lot of things and nothing works for me.
If you find the way, I'd really like to know how you did it !

description.text:
This is a test triangle for checking positioning errors caused by looseness of backlash in delta printers, like the Tiko.

Move the object so that it is centered on Tiko's bed.

Each side is facing one motor. The theory is that each side will reflect the positioning errors of it's facing motor. I have not tested this yet, so corrections on this theory may happen.
I have added letters on each face identifying which motor is closest, Alpha, Beta and Gamma.

This model comes with a free marmalade sandwich.

From the author:
"I bought a small toy bear on Christmas Eve 1956. I saw it left on a shelf in a London store and felt sorry for it. I took it home as a present for my wife Brenda and named it Paddington as we were living near Paddington Station at the time. I wrote some stories about the bear, more for fun than with the idea of having them published. After ten days I found that I had a book on my hands. It wasn’t written specifically for children, but I think I put into it the kind things I liked reading about when I was young." - Michael Bond

I've included a model with built-in supports and one without. I was able to print this model without supports with very little problem. The marmalade sandwich is also included as a separate object. I've removed the hand/suitcase from the model to eliminate the need to supports. They should glue back in with little effort.

Model finished size around 87, 67, 150 mm

description.text:
Chinese 40mm fans often has poor design (too big gap between blades and fan duct). So, using them on a thin air ducts are not efficient, because air tends to come back in the gap between blades and fan duct.

If you have this issue, then this small cover effectively reduces opposite air flow.

It is very easy to try. Just print it and then feel with your hand air flow behind the fan with and without this cap.

remixed_from.author: trth
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Depth Gauge / Dial Gauge Bed Leveling Mount

description.text:
Holds the cheap micrometer available on amazon in place so you could precisely lever your print bed., MADE IN USA Print 2 parts Usage Notes:

  • I am able to get my bed +-0.02mm level in around 2-5min or even less

  • Make sure to heat up the bed before leveling since it could warp,
    • 2.1 Set your Z at around 10-20 so the device is under minimum stress for best result

  • Ride Y up and down until you get same results all the way across
    (I have noticed that my aluminium bed is slightly warped towards the center ~~0.05mm so I simply compensated that on the sides)

  • Repeat on the other side

  • Done!
    • You will need :
  • 4 m3 bolts - to keep it together I used 50mm, (however anything over 25 will do the trick),
  • M3 nuts (Optional) To make it very snug I inserted 2 m3 nuts inside the mount hole of the digital caliper and threaded the middle bolt through them. makes this thing very sturdy and elevates error while moving it to the other side
    • Final Notes:
    as this clips on, there are 2 positions that it will snap to, Make sure you establish which one you are using. I like moving the extruder to the opposite side of this device since it snaps on, there will be a slight flex on your tubes so might as well give them as much room to spread the load and prevent any bending, the results are much more accurate that way as well if you keep the extruder as far away as you can. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0071SKHAW/ref=oh_details_o03_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Link to the Electronic Digital INDICATOR / DEPTH GAGE I got the Idea from trth Thanks man. I have included the Inventor file as well, just split the object in half for printing.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8fJrL2nkTcS

Parameterized handle/bracket allows different shapes and sizes.
The parameters allow size of the thing, thickness, wheter it hsa braces on the ends, whether the braces are straight or arched, and the size of a chamfer on the mounting tabs. Also the screw size is a parameter.

Use the parameters in the OpenSCAD file to make just the right size. I printed the brackets raftless, but I noted that the very plain version needed to be really hard on the platform.
I printed this with 50% fill, one extra shell.
After the thing is printed, if it has braces on the mounting yabs, there will be a thin support shell in between the braces. Just cut this out while you are cleaning up the thing. In the image of a single thing, you can see that there is a thin cylinder in the end.
